title: Girl, Woman, Other by Bernadine Evaristo, review: ‘A wonderful novel’
text:
On Monday night, Bernadine Evaristo co-won the Booker with Margaret Atwood, becoming the first black woman to receive the prize. It’s interesting to note that Girl, Woman, Other, a polyphonic sequence of largely unpunctuated, interconnected stories about 12 black women, features one character on the verge of comparable mainstream recognition: Amma is a gay black theatre writer with a long history on the radical fringe who, when the novel begins, is nervously awaiting the first night of her new play at the National Theatre.

“ ‘What if she’s slated by the critics?’ she thinks, ‘dismissed with a consensus of one-star reviews, what was the great National thinking allowing this rubbishy impostor...
